name: Minneapolis, MN
tagline: Progressive prairie city with lakes, bike paths, and brutal-but-beautiful winters

diversity.summary: Minneapolis is more diverse than raw numbers suggest—significant Somali, Ethiopian, Hmong, and Latino communities give it international flavor. About 19% Black, 10% Hispanic, 6% Asian. However, racial disparities are among nation's worst, and George Floyd's murder highlighted deep systemic issues. On individual level, urban areas are progressive and accepting, but structural racism is real. Twin Cities have work to do.
diversity.diversity_index: 19% Black, 10% Hispanic, 6% Asian; large Somali/Ethiopian populations
diversity.notable: Significant racial justice activism post-2020; city grappling with equity issues

safety.summary: Crime increased post-2020, becoming a political flashpoint. Some neighborhoods saw upticks in property crime and carjackings. However, most residential areas remain safe. Uptown, Northeast, and South Minneapolis neighborhoods vary. Not as safe as peak years but improving. Honest concern compared to pre-2020.

scenery.summary: Minneapolis has 22 lakes within city limits (Chain of Lakes, Lake Calhoun/Bde Maka Ska). Beautiful in summer with trails, parks, and water activities. Fall colors are spectacular. Winter is a snowy wonderland (if you embrace it). Not mountains, but water and greenery are abundant.

climate.summary: Four EXTREME seasons. Winters are brutally cold (sub-zero temps, heavy snow) but the city embraces it with winter activities. Summers are warm and beautiful. Fall is gorgeous. Spring can be muddy. This is a 'if you can handle winter, you'll love it' situation.

culture.summary: Minneapolis is a cultural powerhouse—world-class theater (Guthrie), art (Walker Art Center, Sculpture Garden), music scene (Prince!), Hmong markets, Somali malls, Nordic heritage. Progressive politics, bike culture, farm-to-table dining, craft beer/coffee. Feels sophisticated and authentic. 'Minnesota Nice' is real but can be cliquey.

pros: Beautiful lakes and outdoor recreation within city
cons: WINTER IS BRUTAL—Candace needs to be ready for real cold
Crime increased post-2020 (improving but real concern)
Racial disparities are severe despite diversity
Can be harder to break into social circles ('Minnesota Nice' paradox)
Political climate can be very progressive (may not be 'moderate' enough)

neighborhoods.name: Uptown
neighborhoods.vibe: Urban, artsy, lakes nearby—Minneapolis's young professional hub
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, near lakes, restaurants and nightlife. Some crime concerns post-2020 but still popular. Good for urban adventure.

neighborhoods.name: Northeast Minneapolis (NE MPLS)
neighborhoods.vibe: Arts district turned hip neighborhood—breweries, studios, Eastern European roots
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Artsy, affordable, brewery central. Feels authentic with edge. Great for Josh's explorer vibe. Safe and fun.

neighborhoods.name: Linden Hills
neighborhoods.vibe: Upscale residential near Lake Harriet—family-friendly, tree-lined
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Beautiful, safe, near lake. Less urban energy but excellent quality of life. Good for settling vs exploring.

neighborhoods.name: Tangletown
neighborhoods.vibe: Quiet, tree-lined, community feel—hidden gem near lakes
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Affordable, safe, walkable. Charming without being trendy. Great value. Close to lakes for outdoor time.

neighborhoods.name: Lyn-Lake Area
neighborhoods.vibe: Intersection of urban energy—restaurants, indie shops, nightlife
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, lots of activity, central location. Can feel gritty but authentic. Good restaurant access.
